instruction: How were the machine learning models utilized in predicting the concentrations of potentially toxic elements (PTEs) in the Ipojuca river basin using near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy?
Output: The machine learning models, specifically the random forest algorithm (RF) and partial least squares regression (PLS), were utilized in predicting the concentrations of potentially toxic elements (PTEs) in the Ipojuca river basin using near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy. The models were built using spectral data retrieved from soil and bed sediment samples collected from the river basin. Different spectral preprocessing methods were applied to the data before training the models. The aim was to develop chemometric models that could accurately quantify the concentrations of various PTEs based on the NIR spectral data. The RF models were found to generally provide better results compared to the PLS models. The related study demonstrated that NIR spectroscopy combined with machine learning models can be a viable alternative assessment tool for predicting PTE concentrations, even in large areas with geochemical and pedological heterogeneity.
